title: Present Tense Regular Verbs
description: Master the present tense conjugation of regular Portuguese verbs ending in -ar, -er, and -ir.

grammar.title: Regular -AR Verbs
grammar.content: To conjugate -ar verbs, remove -ar and add: -o, -as, -a, -amos, -am. Example with 'falar' (to speak).

grammar.title: Regular -ER Verbs
grammar.content: To conjugate -er verbs, remove -er and add: -o, -es, -e, -emos, -em. Example with 'comer' (to eat).

grammar.title: Regular -IR Verbs
grammar.content: To conjugate -ir verbs, remove -ir and add: -o, -es, -e, -imos, -em. Example with 'partir' (to leave).

grammar.title: Subject Pronouns
grammar.content: Portuguese subject pronouns: Eu (I), Tu (you-informal), Ele/Ela (he/she), Nós (we), Eles/Elas (they). Pronouns are often omitted since the verb ending shows who is acting.
examples: Falo português. (I speak Portuguese - 'Eu' is optional)
Moras em Lisboa? (Do you live in Lisbon?)

exercises.question: Conjugate: Eu ____ português. (I speak Portuguese) - falar
exercises.explanation: 'Falo' is the first person singular (eu) of 'falar'. Remove -ar, add -o.

exercises.question: Conjugate: Nós ____ em Lisboa. (We live in Lisbon) - morar
exercises.explanation: 'Moramos' is the first person plural (nós) of 'morar'. Remove -ar, add -amos.

exercises.question: What is the correct conjugation: Ela ____ café. (She drinks coffee)
exercises.explanation: 'Bebe' is the third person singular (ela) of 'beber'. Remove -er, add -e.

exercises.question: Conjugate: Eles ____ televisão. (They watch TV) - assistir
exercises.explanation: 'Assistem' is the third person plural (eles) of 'assistir'. Remove -ir, add -em.

exercises.question: Which verb conjugation is correct: Tu ____ no Porto. (You live in Porto)
exercises.explanation: 'Moras' is the second person singular (tu) of 'morar'. Remove -ar, add -as.

culturalNotes.title: Tu vs Você
culturalNotes.content: In European Portuguese, 'tu' (informal you) is very common among friends and family. 'Você' is more formal. In Brazil, 'você' is used much more frequently, even casually.

culturalNotes.title: Dropping Pronouns
culturalNotes.content: Portuguese speakers often drop subject pronouns because the verb ending makes it clear who's acting. 'Falo português' (I speak Portuguese) is more natural than 'Eu falo português'.
